Authors: Hutabarat R., Sen Rimo T.H., Meilani, Andika A.
Title: Improving delivery performance by using simulation, FMEA, and FTA
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hutabarat, R., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Sen Rimo, T.H., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Meilani, Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Andika, A., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Delivery performance is one of the indications of enterprise's success to provide products to customers. In this research, simulation is done to measure the delivery performance and all the processes included in delivery process. In fact, every process has their own risks could delay delivery process that the delivery performance is reduced. The methods used to identify the risks and the causes are Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA) and Fault Tree Analysis (FTA). Risks analysis is done with the help of Pareto diagrams and scatter plot to determine the risks need to be corrected immediately. The proposed improvements are integrating the systems in form of e-cargo ready and implementing bar-coding. After the proposed e-cargo ready applied and being simulated, the delivery performance in terms of average total time reduced by 29,398%. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: Fault tree analysis; Risk analysis; Delivery performance; Delivery process; Failure mode and effects analysis; Fault tree analyses (FTA); FMEA; Improving delivery performance; Pareto diagrams; Simulation; Risk assessment

Authors: Safira D., Safitri F., Kamal H., Meilani, Sujana C.M., Andika A.
Title: Time accelaration of offshore EPC project using FMEA, FTA, CPM and crashing method at PT XYZ
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Safira, D., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Safitri, F., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Kamal, H., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Meilani, Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Sujana, C.M., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Andika, A., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The pipe instalation of offshore EPC project has high risk of cost overruns due to the uncertainty of weather, human errors, pipe fabriction process, etc. All of those risks will cause the project delay. The optimiziation of risk based project scheduling can reduce the risks. Risk management can be optimized with combining some methods, such as Failure Mode and Effect Analysis (FMEA), Fault Tree Analysis (FTA), Critical Path Method (CPM) and Crashing Project method. The combination of these methods are used to do the data analysis in order to reduce the project total duration. Based on analysis using FMEA, FTA, CPM and crashing project method, the total of project duration can be reduced from 499 days to 489 days with Rp. 6.822.472,- as the additional cost of workers. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: Crashing Project method; Critical Path Method; Failure Mode and Effect Analysis; Fault Tree Analysis
Index Keywords: Critical path analysis; Offshore oil well production; Offshore pipelines; Risk assessment; Risk management; Turnaround time; Additional costs; Critical path method; Failure mode and effect analysis; Fault tree analyses (FTA); Project delays; Project duration; Project methods; Project scheduling; Fault tree analysis

Title: The effect of thermal treatments on recycled alternative aggregates toward concrete properties
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Meilani, Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Dharma, F.C., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The objective of this research was to obtain the physical and chemical characteristics of the recycled waste material such as bricks, roof tiles, and ceramics waste. Chemical composition checked with XRF method. The physical characteristics were obtained by burning the recycled materials at 1000°C with ladle burner machine. SNI 03-2834-2000 was used as guideline in concrete making process. It could be seen that on the recycled materials had silica as their highest chemical composition. The specific gravity of recycled materials increased after the burning process while water absorption decreased after the burning process. Thermal treatment improved the quality of recycled alternative aggregates. Crystallization process started at 1000°C, resulted the decreasing value of material porosity and hardness. The decreasing value of concrete compressive strength was less than 8 % at the 25 % substitution of both ceramics and roof tiles. It showed that the recycled materials could be used as structural concrete based on SNI (Indonesian National Standard) © 2018 Institute of Physics Publishing. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: chemical content; compressive strength; physic characteristic; thermal treatment; waste material

Authors: Setyandito O., Wijayanti Y., Alwan M., Chayati C., Meilani
Title: The assessment of Urban Storm Inundation
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Agriculture Department, Faculty of Agriculture, Institute of Agriculture Stiper, Yogyakarta, Indonesia; Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, University of Mataram, West Nusa Tenggara, Indonesia; Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Wiraraja University, Sumenep, Madura, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Setyandito, O., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Wijayanti, Y., Agriculture Department, Faculty of Agriculture, Institute of Agriculture Stiper, Yogyakarta, Indonesia; Alwan, M., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, University of Mataram, West Nusa Tenggara, Indonesia; Chayati, C., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Wiraraja University, Sumenep, Madura, Indonesia; Meilani, Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: A Sustainable and integrated plan in order to solve urban storm inundation problem, is an urgent issue in Indonesia. A reliable and complete datasets of urban storm inundation area in Indonesia should become its basis to give clear description of inundation area for formulating the best solution. In this study, Statistics Indonesia data in thirty three provinces were assessed during 2000 until 2012 providing data series of urban flood area, flood frequency and land cover changes. Drainage system condition in big cities should be well understood to ensure its infrastructure condition and performance. If inundation occurred, it can be concluded that there is drainage system problem. Inundation data is also important for drainage system design process in the future. The study result is provided estimation of urban storm inundation area based on calculation of Statistics Indonesia data. Moreover, this study is preceded by analyzing and reviewing the capacity of existing drainage channel, using case study of Mataram, West Nusa Tenggara. Rainfall data was obtained from three rainfall stations surround Mataram City. The storm water quantity was calculated using three different approaches as follows: 1) Rational Method; 2) Summation of existing inundation and surface run off discharge; 3) Discharge calculation from existing channel dimensions. After that, the result of these approaches was compared. The storm water quantity gap was concluded as quantity of inundation. The result shows that 36% of drainage channel in Brenyok Kanan River sub system could not accommodate the storm water runoff in this area, which causing inundation. The redesign of drainage channel using design discharge from Rational Method approach should be performed. Within area with the lowest level topography, a construction of detention or storage pond is essential to prevent inundation in this area. Furthermore, the benefits and drawbacks of the statistics database are discussed. Recommendations include utilizing more refined urban land use typologies that can better represent physical alteration of hydrological pathways. © 2017 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: Drainage Channel Capacity; Inundation; Statistics data Indonesia; Storm Water Quantity
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Floods; Land use; Rain; Runoff; Storms; Systems analysis; Channel dimension; Discharge calculation; Drainage channels; Indonesia; Inundation; Land-cover change; Storm water runoff; Stormwaters; Drainage

Authors: Meilani, Syafalni S., Santoso Y., Green Malau G.
Title: Rainwater quality improvement using zeolite, activated carbon, limestone and preheated 400°C limestone
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Civil Engineering Department, National Institute of Sciences and Technology, Jakarta, 12640, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Meilani, Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Syafalni, S., Civil Engineering Department, National Institute of Sciences and Technology, Jakarta, 12640, Indonesia; Santoso, Y., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Green Malau, G., Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Resources of clean water have decreased significantly in recent years, one of the reasons is water pollution. Utilization of rainwater as clean water resource is among the best option, especially in big cities like Jakarta. Excessive rainwater during wet season can be saved and used as the source of clean water during dry seasons. However, rainwater contains some pollutants, thus suitable treatment method should be utilized to improve its quality as clean water for daily needs. This study compared the effectiveness of zeolite, limestone, activated carbon and preheated 400°C limestone as additive to improve the rainwater quality. Results show that both limestone and preheated 400°C limestone improve all the parameters observed, meanwhile both activated carbon and zeolite had shown to have detrimental effect on water conductivity. © The Authors, published by EDP Sciences, 2017.
Index Keywords: Activated carbon; Limestone; Pollution; Water pollution; Water resources; Zeolites; Clean water resources; Clean waters; Dry seasons; Jakarta; Rainwater quality; Treatment methods; Water conductivity; Wet season; Activated carbon treatment

Title: Obtaining the natural frequency of stiffened plate with modified bolotin method
Source title: International Journal of Applied Engineering Research
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9, West Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Meilani, Civil Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9, West Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Usually the plate’s natural frequency can be found with a lot of methods. Unfortunately those methods are limited to the plate with pin supports at all edges. Bolotin proposed asymptotic method applied to rectangular plate with more accurately result [1]. This paper will discuss how to find the natural frequency of the plate with semirigid supports at all edges using Modified Bolotin Method. Modified Bolotin Method can simplify the calculation of natural frequency of the plate with semirigid support at all edges.The assumption is the homogeneous plate has constant thickness. The plate is also assumed as linear elastic and orthotropic. The stiffeners of the plate are two beams at one axis direction. The natural frequency of the plate and the eigen vector will be solved using Modified Bolotin Method. While the numeric calculation will be solved using Mathematica 5.2 and Microsoft Excel 2003. © 2014 Research India Publications.
Author Keywords: Modified bolotin method; Semirigid support; Stiffened plate
References: Alisjahbana, S.W., (2002) Dinamika Struktur Pelat, , Jakarta: Jurusan Teknik Sipil Universitas Tarumanagara; Alisjahbana, S.W., Dynamic Response of Clamped Orthotropic Plates to Dynamic Moving Loads (2004) 13thWorld Conference onEarthquake Engineerin, , paper No. 3176; Elishakoff, I.B., Vibration Analysis of Clamped Square Orthotropic Plate (1974) AIAA Journal, 12 (7), pp. 921-924. , July; Kadid, A., Stiffened Plates Subjected To Uniform Blast Loading (2008) Algeria: Journal of Civil Engineering and Management, pp. 155-161; Langdon, G.S., (2002) The Response of Stiffened Square Plates Subjected To Localised Blast Loading, , UK: WIT Press; Meilani, (2010) Respons Dinamik Lantai Bangunan Dengan Pengaku Akibat Beban Ledakan, , Tesis Pascasarjana Teknik Sipil, Fakultas Teknik Universitas Tarumanagara, Jakarta; Meilani, Proceeding: Modified Bolotin Method to Obtain The Natural Frequency of Stiffened Plate with Semirigid Support (2012) International Conference on Advances Science and Contemporary Engineering 2012 (ICASCE 2012), , Jakarta, Indonesia, October, 24th -25th, 2012; Paz, M., (1987) Dinamika Struktur Teori dan Perhitungan, , Jakarta: Erlangga; Pevzner, P., Weller, T., Berkovitz, A., 2000. Title: Compressive strength and water absorption of pervious concrete that using the fragments of ceramics and roof tiles
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9, West-Jakarta 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Prahara, E., Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9, West-Jakarta 11480, Indonesia; Meilani, Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9, West-Jakarta 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Pervious concrete was introduced in America in 2003, popularized by Dan Brown and used as a rigid pavement in the open parking lot. Rigid pavement using pervious concrete can absorb water in the surface to go straight through the concrete to the ground below.This water flow is one of the benefit of using the pervious concrete. Using of wastes such as broken roof and ceramics tiles are not commonly used in Indonesia. Utilization these kind of wastes is predicted lower the compressive strength of pervious concrete as they are used as a substitute for coarse aggregate.In this research, pervious concrete is made using a mixture of the fragment of ceramics and roof tiles.This research using broken ceramics and roof tiles with a grain size that loose from 38 mm sieve, retained on 19 mm sieve and the coarse aggregate from crushed stone that loose 12.5 mm sieve, retained on 9.5 mm sieve. The water cement ratio is 0.3 and to assist the mixing process, the addition of addictive in pervious concrete is used.The size of coarse aggregate used in the mixture affects the strength of pervious concrete. The larger the size of aggregate, the obtained compressive strength becomes smaller. It also affects the density of pervious concrete. The using of mixture of ceramics and roof tiles only reduce 2 MPa of pervious concrete compressive strength so this mixture can be used as a substitute for coarse aggregate with a maximum portion of 30 %. The high porosity of the specimens causes the reduction of pervious concrete density that affect the compressive strength. This high level of porosity can be seen from the high level of water absorption that exceed the required limit of water infiltration. © Owned by the authors, published by EDP Sciences, 2014.
Author Keywords: Ceramics tile fragment; Compressive strength; Pervious concrete; Roof tile fragments

Authors: Wajong A.M.R., Khristian Edi N.S., Sofyan, Meilani
Title: Information system of cloud computing, integrated with a communication system on the robot-supporting urban search and rescue in disaster areas
Affiliations: Department of Industrial Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Department of Computer Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Department of Civil Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Wajong, A.M.R., Department of Industrial Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Khristian Edi, N.S., Department of Industrial Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Sofyan, Department of Computer Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Meilani, Department of Civil Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Disasters occur oftenly in Indonesia, where its management is still intact from the application of technology, particularly information technology. Efforts of relief conducted for the victims are still very conventional. Meanwhile, the development of information technology has advanced considerably and can be applied to help the victims with the creation of robots that can get inside crevices of the buildings which are damaged due to disasters. Moreover, the implementation of cloud computing technology allows interested experts to not attend the site of disaster, making this technology very useful. The applied technology is also very environmentally friendly as it will very much be able to preserve the environment which results in significantly immense benefits for the safety of the victims. © Medwell Journals, 2014.
Author Keywords: Cloud computing; Disaster; Information technology; Robots; Victims

Authors: Soebandrija K.E.N., Wajong A.M.R., Meilani, Sofyan
Title: Indonesia situation and perspective: Urban Search and Rescue (USAR) within Emergency Response Systems in Confined Space Disaster
Source title: International Journal of Applied Engineering Research
Affiliations: Industrial Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Syahdan Campus, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Bina Nusantara University, Syahdan Campus, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Computer Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Syahdan Campus, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Soebandrija, K.E.N., Industrial Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Syahdan Campus, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia, Bina Nusantara University, Syahdan Campus, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Wajong, A.M.R., Industrial Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Syahdan Campus, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Meilani, Civil Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Syahdan Campus, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Sofyan, Computer Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Syahdan Campus, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This paper constitutes the discussion of Urban Search and Rescue (USAR) from Indonesia Situation and Perspectives, within Emergency Response Systems (ERS) in Confined Space Disaster (CSD). This paper constitutes the continuation of future research of prior International Conferences and Journals that were presented and /or will be published by Soebandrija, Wajong, Meilani and Sofyan (2013) that are multidiscipline views of Industrial, Computer, and Civil Engineering. Yet, there are several novelty and new discussions in this paper. First, as the background of this paper and prior papers: a. as overview, is to conduct research of USAR in any places in the world that happened in Confined Space Disaster, and that are Searched and Rescued using Serpentine Robot; b. as focus on this paper is to elaborate the Indonesia Situation and Perspectives to enrich the ERS and CSD Managements pertaining the similarities and differences of Indonesia Situation as compared to other countries’ situations. Furthermore, as the specific background, The geographical position of Indonesia is at the confluence of three major plates of the world (Australia, Eurasia and the Pacific) and nine other small plates. This position added to the situation that Indonesia is located at ring of fire position, having more than 66 volcanoes. This condition also causes the volcanic earthquake and vulnerable to the Disaster Situation that require ERS and CSD. Second, as the objective of this paper is to assess and have the lesson learned from the mentioned similarities and differences, to ameliorate the Disaster Control and Management in current and future occurrence in Indonesia and abroad. Third, as the methodology in this paper constitutes observation, field visit and collaboration with the all experts in Government and Civilian’s Key Person. In addition to the field visit and collaboration, in this paper there is laboratory experiment as relate to production of prototype and final product, as relate to prior papers that discussed serpentine robot for prototype and ongoing development for the improvement for the final serpentine products. Fourth, the audience of this paper are the Government and Civilian and related person involved in ERS and CSD Management to have improved skills and collaboration to handle the situation with safety consideration for the rescuers and the victims. Fourth, as the result, this paper provides the Indonesia situation and perspectives, and its guidance for the ERS and CSD. Fifth, as the conclusion, this paper is beneficial to enhance the prior research, and to trigger further continuous improvement for constantly changing and challenging ERS and CSD, not only in Indonesia but also in other countries. © Research India Publications.
Author Keywords: Confined space rescue; Emergency Response Systems; Government and civilian collaboration; Indonesia; Serpentine robot

Title: Modified bolotin method to obtain the natural frequency of stiffened plate with semirigid support
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9 West, Jakarta 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Meilani, Bina Nusantara University, KH Syahdan 9 West, Jakarta 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: There are a lot of methods in finding the plate s natural frequency, but those methods are limited to the plate with pin supports at all edges.This paper will discuss how to find the plate s natural frequency with semirigid supports at all edges using the Modified Bolotin Method. The plate is assumed as a long thin rectangular plate with constant thickness. The plate is also linear elastic, homogeneous, and orthotropic. This plate will be given two beams as stiffeners at one axis direction.The plate s natural frequency and eigen vector will be solved with Modified Bolotin Method. The using of Modified Bolotin Method can simplify the calculation of plate s natural frequency with semirigid supports at all edges. The numeric calculation can be done with Microsoft Excel 2003 dan Mathematica 5.2. © 2012 Elsevier B.V.
References: Alisjahbana, S.W., (2002) Dinamika Struktur Pelat, , Jakarta : Jurusan Teknik Sipil Universitas Tarumanagara; Alisjahbana, S.W., Dynamic response of clamped orthotropic plates to dynamic moving loads (2004) 13th World Conference on Earthquake Engineerin, , paper No. 3176; Elishakoff, I.B., Vibration analysis of clamped square orthotropic plate (1974) AIAA Journal, 12 (7), pp. 921-924. , July 1974; Kadid, A., Stiffened plates subjected to uniform blast loading (2008) Algeria: Journal of Civil Engineering and Management, pp. 155-161; Langdon, G.S., (2002) The Response of Stiffened Square Plates Subjected to Localised Blast Loading, , UK: WIT Press; Meilani, (2010) Respons Dinamik Lantai Bangunan Dengan Pengaku Akibat Beban Ledakan, , Tesis Pascasarjana Teknik Sipil, Fakultas Teknik Universitas Tarumanagara, Jakarta; Paz, M., (1987) Dinamika Struktur Teori Dan Perhitungan, , Jakarta : Erlangga; Pevzner, P., Weller, T., Berkovitz, A., Further modification of bolotin method in vibration analysis of rectangular plates (2000) AIAA Journal, 38 (9), pp. 1725-1729. , September 2000; Szilard, R., (1989) Teori Dan Analisis Pelat : Metode Klasik Dan Numerik, , Jakarta : Erlangga; Troitsky, M.S., (1999) Stiffened Plates-Bending, Stability and Vibrations, , Canada: Elsevier Scientific Publishing Company
